News_Title: BYD (SEHK:1211) Valuation Check As P/E Premium Contrasts With Cash Flow Upside Signals
News_Content:
Hong Kong
/Auto
/SEHK:1211
BYD (SEHK:1211) Valuation Check As P/E Premium Contrasts With Cash Flow Upside Signals
Simply Wall St
January 28, 2026
Recent share performance and business scale
Without a clear single news catalyst, you might be looking at BYD (SEHK:1211) simply because its recent share performance and business size stand out among Hong Kong listed auto and battery groups.
Over the past month, BYD shares have returned about 5.9%, while the past 3 months show a modest 1.3% decline. On a 1 year view, the total return figure provided is 14.2%.
The company reports revenue of CN¬•841.1b and net income of CN¬•38.3b. This reflects a large-scale operation across automobiles, batteries and related services. Annual revenue growth is given as 10.8%, with net income growth at 16.3%.
At the last close of HK$102.80, some valuation metrics in the data suggest a potential gap between market price and certain fair value estimates. However, these approaches depend heavily on the assumptions behind each model.
See our latest analysis for BYD.
Recent trading points to rebuilding momentum, with a 1 day share price return of 4.6% and a 7 day share price return of 3.8%, set against a 1 year total shareholder return of 14.2% that reflects steadier long term gains.
If BYD has you thinking more broadly about the auto space, it could be a good time to see what else is on the move among auto manufacturers.
So with BYD trading at HK$102.80 alongside fair value and price target estimates that sit higher, is the current share price a genuine gap you can exploit, or is the market already factoring in future growth?
Price to earnings of 21.7x: Is it justified?
On the latest numbers, BYD trades on a P/E of 21.7x, while our fair value work points to a lower P/E of 13.8x and the shares sit below some cash flow based estimates such as the SWS DCF model fair value of HK$136 versus the last close at HK$102.80.
The P/E ratio compares the current share price with earnings per share and is a common way for investors to judge how much they are paying for each unit of profit. For a large auto and battery group like BYD, a higher P/E can reflect expectations for further earnings progress as well as the breadth of its businesses across vehicles, batteries and related services.
Here, the 21.7x P/E sits above both the Asian auto industry average of 18.2x and a peer average of 8.3x. This suggests the market is assigning BYD a richer earnings tag than many regional and peer names. Compared with the estimated fair P/E of 13.8x, the gap is also wide. This highlights a level that the market could move towards if sentiment or earnings expectations change.
Explore the SWS fair ratio for BYD
Result: Price to earnings of 21.7x (OVERVALUED)
However, you still need to watch for earnings expectations resetting if sentiment toward higher P/E auto names cools or if analyst price targets are revised lower.
Find out about the key risks to this BYD narrative.
Another view: Cash flow says something different
If you put the earnings multiple to one side and look at our SWS DCF model, you get a different message. On this view, BYD at HK$102.80 sits about 24.4% below an estimated fair value of HK$136, which points to potential upside rather than stretch.
That gap matters because it shows how sensitive conclusions can be to the tool you use, and to the assumptions built into it. If profits or cash flows play out differently, could this apparent cushion shrink or widen from here?
Look into how the SWS DCF model arrives at its fair value.
1211 Discounted Cash Flow as at Jan 2026
Simply Wall St performs a discounted cash flow (DCF) on every stock in the world every day (check out BYD for example). We show the entire calculation in full. You can track the result in your watchlist or portfolio and be alerted when this changes, or use our stock screener to discover 876 undervalued stocks based on their cash flows. If you save a screener we even alert you when new companies match - so you never miss a potential opportunity.

If this view does not quite match your own read of the numbers, you can test the assumptions yourself and shape a personalised thesis in just a few minutes with Do it your way.

News_Title: Tesla poised to be early winner as Canada opens door to Chinese-made EVs
News_Content:
Tesla poised to be early winner as Canada opens door to Chinese-made EVs
Reuters
January 19, 2026 3 min read
In this article:
TSLA
+3.32%
PSNY
-8.02%
BYDDF
-2.94%
NIO
-1.47%
GELHY
-3.49%
BEIJING/SHANGHAI, Jan 19 (Reuters) - Tesla (TSLA) is poised to be one of the first automakers to benefit from Canada's move to remove 100% tariffs on Chinese-made EVs, thanks to its early efforts to ship cars from its Shanghai plant there and its established Canadian sales network, experts say.
Under the deal announced last Friday, Canada will allow up to 49,000 vehicles to be imported annually ‚Äåfrom China with a tariff of 6.1% on most-favoured nation terms. Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney said the quota could rise to reach 70,000 vehicles within five years.
However, under one clause ‚Äåin the agreement, half of the quota will be reserved for vehicles under 35,000 CAD ($25,189). Tesla model prices are all above that number.
While many Chinese automakers will be keen to seize the opportunity as they expand exports, Tesla has an advantage as it in 2023 already equipped its Shanghai plant, its biggest and most cost-efficient factory globally, to build and export a Canada-specific version of its Model Y.
A Tesla China-made Model 3 vehicle owner sits inside a car during a delivery event at Tesla's Shanghai factory in China January 7, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song ¬∑ REUTERS / Reuters
The U.S. automaker had that same year started shipping the car ‚Å†from Shanghai to Canada, boosting Canadian imports of automobiles ‚Äåfrom China to its largest port, Vancouver, by 460% year over year to 44,356 in 2023.
But it was forced to stop in 2024 and switched to shipping from its U.S. and Berlin factories after Ottawa imposed 100% tariffs, citing ‚Äça wish to counter what they called China's intentional state-directed policy of overcapacity.
Now, it ships Model Ys produced in Berlin to Canada, but more variants such as cheaper Model 3s are mostly built in China.
"This new agreement could allow resumption of those exports rather quickly," said Sam Fiorani, vice president of research firm AutoForecast Solutions.
NasdaqGS - Nasdaq Real Time Price
‚Ä¢
USD
Tesla, Inc. (TSLA)
Follow
View Quote Details
430.41
+13.84
(+3.32%)
At close: January 30 at 4:00:02 PM EST
429.63
-0.78
(-0.18%)
After hours: January 30 at 7:59:58 PM EST
Advanced Chart
Tesla has an existing network of 39 stores in Canada, whereas Chinese rivals such as BYD and Nio do not yet have a sales presence ‚Äåthere, and it can also likely move faster with marketing plans as it only has four core models, far fewer than its Chinese competitors.
"Tesla indeed has an advantage with its offering of a few models, versions and simple production lines so that it can be flexible to sell cars produced in any country in any markets to achieve the best cost efficiency," said Yale Zhang, managing director at Shanghai-based consultancy AutoForesight.
Tesla did not immediately respond to a Reuters' request for comment.
Other brands that exported cars made in China to Canada before the tariffs included Volvo and Polestar, which are both ‚Å†owned by China's automaking group Geely.

News_Title: After winning global EV crown, BYD faces new challenge with profitability test
News_Content:
After winning global EV crown, BYD faces new challenge with profitability test
January 12, 2026
1211.HK
97.75
(0.0%)
002594.SHE
90.89
(0.0%)
Follow
China‚Äôs EV giant overtook Tesla in unit sales last year, but margin pressure, overseas risks and a controversial financing model raise questions on whether it can still deliver shareholder value
Key Takeaways:
BYD‚Äôs global sales surge has not translated into higher profitability, as the company faces pressures from an ongoing price war at home and falling profits per vehicle
The unwinding of the leading EV maker‚Äôs supplier‚Äëfinancing scheme and rising overseas challenges threaten to lift its debt ratio and dampen its expansion
   By Xia Fei
Chinese electric carmaker BYD Co. Ltd. (1211.HK; 002594.SZ), whose name stands for ‚ÄúBuild Your Dreams,‚Äù may have just achieved one such vision: overtaking Elon Musk‚Äôs Tesla (TSLA.US) as the world‚Äôs biggest seller of electric vehicles (EVs). But that vision may be coming at a cost, quite literally, as BYD‚Äôs dream puts its profitability on a dangerously downward trajectory that sometimes comes with such aggressive expansion.
The Shenzhen-based company basked in the global spotlight earlier this month when it revealed that it sold 2.26 million EVs globally in 2025, driven by 145% year-on-year growth abroad. By comparison, Tesla‚Äôs battery-powered car deliveries fell 8.6% to 1.6 million last year, the largest annual drop in its history.
That resounding trading of places looks like a sweeping victory for BYD. Within China, where domestic brands already reign, Tesla‚Äôs sales fell for the first time by more than 5% to around 620,000 vehicles ‚Äî the first decline since its Shanghai gigafactory opened in 2020. BYD also outpaced Tesla in sales both in Britain and Germany, a sign that Chinese brands are starting to make headway into more affluent markets.
Such stark contrast marks a powerful riposte for Wang Chuanfu, a low-profile chemist who founded BYD as a battery maker in 1995, against Musk, who mocked the Chinese company as a rival more than a decade ago. Beyond car making, BYD has also invested heavily in energy storage and smart driving systems, moves that could help offset margin pressure amid a worsening price war that began in China and is rapidly being exported abroad by Chinese EV brands.
BYD‚Äôs triumph owes in no small part to its heavy presence at the lower end of the market. Its Seagull models start at around just $8,000, and already include the company‚Äôs own ‚ÄúGod‚Äôs Eye‚Äù self-driving system. That‚Äôs miles ahead of Tesla, whose entry-level Model 3 starts at $35,000 and has only gained partial approval to operate assisted driving in China.
But investors should think twice before jumping on the BYD bandwagon. Despite its triumph in scaling up rapidly, a much tougher battle for BYD is just starting: how to translate its huge volumes into higher profits.
In last year‚Äôs third quarter, BYD reported its net profit slumped by 32.6% to 7.8 billion yuan ($1.1 billion), representing its steepest fall in over four years. Revenue also fell for the first time in over five years to 195 billion yuan, a sharp reversal from its strong double-digit growth in 2023 and 2024.
By some measures, BYD‚Äôs profitability is still competitive with Tesla. Its gross margin was 17.9% in last year‚Äôs third quarter, roughly equal to Tesla‚Äôs 18%. But a Morgan Stanley report showed BYD‚Äôs per-vehicle profit fell to just 4,800 yuan in last year‚Äôs second quarter, down from 8,000 yuan the previous quarter ‚Äî a fraction of Tesla‚Äôs roughly $6,000 per vehicle in 2024.
Challenge of staying profitable
Cutthroat competition in China, where rivals race to sell cars on thin margins, and profits remain elusive for most companies, threatens to further compress BYD‚Äôs profitability. Higher vehicle purchase taxes, reduced government subsidies for lower-end EVs and ongoing competition will likely mean a more brutal year for BYD and other Chinese car brands ahead.
At the same time, China‚Äôs EV market is showing signs of slowing sharply after several years of rapid growth. Analysts at S&P Global predict China‚Äôs car sales ‚Äì roughly half of which now come from new energy vehicles (NEVs) ‚Äì will fall in China in 2026, leaving BYD and its peers little choice but to subsidize consumers further, squeezing margins again.
As pressures mount at home, BYD is racing to localize production on a mass scale in Southeast Asia, Latin America and Europe, partly to sidestep tariffs and quicken delivery cycles. But building plants overseas is now a far more complex undertaking, especially as governments in countries from Brazil to Mexico scrutinize BYD‚Äôs plans to build local factories, and China itself worries about transferring cutting-edge technologies to those markets.
Another overlooked uncertainty for the world‚Äôs new EV king comes from government pressure that has forced the company to quietly dismantle a supply chain financing scheme that long helped to power its relentless expansion.
Dubbed Dilian, BY

News_Title: Is BYD (SEHK:1211) Price Missing The Mark After Recent EV Demand Headlines
News_Content:
Is BYD (SEHK:1211) Price Missing The Mark After Recent EV Demand Headlines
Simply Wall St
January 10, 2026 5 min read
In this article:
BYDDF
-2.94%
BYDDY
-3.32%
Wondering whether BYD‚Äôs current share price actually lines up with its underlying worth, or if the market is missing something you can use to your advantage.
BYD shares closed at HK$94.55, with a 7 day return of a 4.3% decline and a 30 day return of a 3.3% decline, while the 1 year return stands at 14.1% and the 3 year and 5 year returns are 26.9% and 19.2% respectively.
Recent news around electric vehicle demand, competition among global automakers, and policy support for new energy vehicles has kept investor attention on companies like BYD. These themes help frame how the market is currently thinking about growth potential and risk for the stock.
BYD records a valuation score of 1 out of 6, which suggests only one of six valuation checks signals the shares as undervalued. Next, we will look at what different valuation approaches say about that, before finishing with a way to think about value that goes beyond the usual ratios.
BYD scores just 1/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown.
Approach 1: BYD Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis
A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model projects a company‚Äôs future cash flows and then discounts them back to today‚Äôs value to estimate what the business might be worth right now.
For BYD, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, working in CN¬•. The latest twelve month free cash flow is a cash outflow of CN¬•29.1b, so the model relies on future projections. Analysts provide estimates for several years, and Simply Wall St then extrapolates further to build a 10 year path. By 2035, projected free cash flow is CN¬•101.3b, with discounted values provided for each year along the way.
Bringing all those projected cash flows back to today gives an estimated intrinsic value of CN¬•115.23 per share, compared with the current share price of HK$94.55. On this basis, the DCF suggests BYD trades at about a 17.9% discount, which indicates that the shares are undervalued relative to these cash flow assumptions.
Result: UNDERVALUED
Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests BYD is undervalued by 17.9%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 877 more undervalued stocks based on cash flows.
1211 Discounted Cash Flow as at Jan 2026
Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for BYD.
Approach 2: BYD Price vs Earnings
For a profitable business like BYD, the P/E ratio is a useful way to relate what you pay for each share to the earnings the company generates per share. It gives you a quick sense of how much of those earnings the market is currently willing to pay for.

News_Title: How Surpassing Tesla In Global EV Sales At BYD (SEHK:1211) Has Changed Its Investment Story
News_Content:
How Surpassing Tesla In Global EV Sales At BYD (SEHK:1211) Has Changed Its Investment Story
Simply Wall St
January 7, 2026 3 min read
In this article:
BYDDF
-2.94%
BYDDY
-3.32%
TSLA
+3.32%
BYD Company Limited has reported unaudited 2025 figures showing full-year vehicle sales and production rising versus 2024, even as December volumes eased, while the group also reshaped its UK leadership and continued building out its dealer network.
These results confirm that BYD has overtaken Tesla as the world‚Äôs largest seller of battery electric vehicles, underscoring how its global expansion is progressing despite slower growth and intense price competition at home.
We‚Äôll now examine how BYD surpassing Tesla in global battery electric vehicle sales reframes the company‚Äôs investment narrative and future positioning.
AI is about to change healthcare. These 29 stocks are working on everything from early diagnostics to drug discovery. The best part - they are all under $10b in market cap - there's still time to get in early.
What Is BYD's Investment Narrative?
For BYD, the crux of the investment case is whether you believe it can turn its new global scale in battery electric vehicles into durable profitability, despite slower growth and fierce price pressure at home. The latest unaudited 2025 figures show full-year sales and production still up year on year, but with a weaker December and a trimmed sales target, which keeps near term demand and pricing firmly in focus as key catalysts. BYD overtaking Tesla as the largest BEV seller repositions the story toward global execution quality, product breadth and export momentum, while the UK leadership reshuffle and dealer build-out underline how seriously management is treating Europe as a growth offset to China. That said, the softer exit to 2025 may increase investor attention on margins and capital discipline.
However, one risk in particular may matter more than the headline EV sales win. BYD's shares have been on the rise but are still potentially undervalued by 14%. Find out what it's worth.
Exploring Other Perspectives
SEHK:1211 1-Year Stock Price Chart
Investors in the Simply Wall St Community have 24 fair value views on BYD, stretching from HK$114.83 to a very large HK$449.47. That spread sits against recent concerns about decelerating unit growth and China price pressure, which could influence how sustainably the company‚Äôs new BEV leadership position translates into future financial performance.
Explore 24 other fair value estimates on BYD - why the stock might be worth just HK$114.83!
Build Your Own BYD Narrative
Disagree with this assessment? Create your own narrative in under 3 minutes - extraordinary investment returns rarely come from following the herd.

News_Title: First Look: Futures Climb, FTSE 10,000, BYD Tops Tesla
News_Content:
GURUFOCUS.COM
Latest News
USA
Semiconductors
NVDA
First Look: Futures Climb, FTSE 10,000, BYD Tops Tesla
GuruFocus News
01/02/2026 20:38
Stock News
U.S. futures rise on first trading day: Tech leaders Nvidia (NVDA, Financial), Palantir (PLTR, Financial), Apple (AAPL, Financial), Alphabet (GOOGL, Financial), and Microsoft (MSFT, Financial) advanced premarket as S&P 500 and Nasdaq-100 futures gained, with the tech ETF (XLK, Financial) also higher. Source: CNBC, Yahoo Finance.
FTSE 100 briefly tops 10,000: London‚Äôs blue-chip index crossed 10,000 for the first time as semis rallied (ASML (ASML, Financial), TSMC (TSM, Financial)) and Orsted (CPH:ORSTED, Financial) rose on legal action in the U.S. wind market; gains cooled later. Source: CNBC, BBC.
BYD set to overtake Tesla in annual EV sales: BYD (HKG:1211, Financial) reported 2025 battery EV sales of ~2.26M, positioning it ahead of Tesla (TSLA, Financial), amid strong China competition; peers XPeng (XPEV, Financial), NIO (NIO, Financial), Li Auto (LI, Financial) and Xiaomi (HKG:1810, Financial) also grew. Source: BBC, CNBC.
Gold and silver notch best year since 1979: Safe‚Äëhaven demand and a weaker dollar powered outsized 2025 gains, with gold and silver ETFs (GLD, SLV) seeing heavy inflows into year‚Äëend. Source: NBC News.
Orsted challenges U.S. halt of Revolution Wind: Orsted (CPH:ORSTED) filed for an injunction against the U.S. lease suspension of its ~$5B offshore wind JV, saying the project is 87% complete. Source: CNBC, WJAR.
Street‚Äôs 2026 outlook: moderate gains: After a 2025 three‚Äëpeat, strategists see further S&P 500 advances led by AI beneficiaries like Nvidia (NVDA), Microsoft (MSFT), Apple (AAPL), Tesla (TSLA) and Palantir (PLTR), while warning on valuations and policy risks. Source: CNN Business, Business Insider.
Crypto tax-reporting rules kick in: The U.K. and dozens of countries began CARF-aligned reporting, requiring exchanges (e.g., Coinbase (COIN, Financial)) to share user transaction data with tax authorities. Source: BBC, PYMNTS.
Dividend themes spotlighted: Income coverage highlighted high‚Äëyield picks such as Verizon (VZ, Financial), AT&T (T, Financial), and Altria (MO, Financial), plus durable dividend names Johnson & Johnson (JNJ, Financial) and Walmart (WMT, Financial), reflecting investor focus on steady cash returns. Source: Yahoo Finance, Motley Fool.
Memory crunch may lift device prices: Surging AI data‚Äëcenter demand for DRAM/HBM is pressuring supply, with Micron (MU, Financial), Samsung (KRX:005930, Financial) and SK hynix (KRX:000660, Financial) benefiting as PC/smartphone OEMs face higher bill‚Äëof‚Äëmaterials costs. Source: BBC, Engadget.
Buffett hands CEO role to Abel: Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B, Financial) founder Warren Buffett (Trades, Portfolio) formally retired as CEO, saying the conglomerate is well‚Äëpositioned for the next century under Greg Abel, while remaining as chairman. Source: CNBC, NPR.
States, NYC roll out 2026 wage and labor changes: Nearly two dozen U.S. states raised minimum wages, while New York City expanded safe/sick time‚Äîmoves affecting large employers across sectors including Walmart (WMT). Source: Dallas Morning News, CBS New York.
Hangzhou emerges as China‚Äôs physical‚ÄëAI hub: The city‚Äôs ecosystem‚Äîfrom giants like Alibaba (BABA, Financial) to robotics startups‚Äîadvances embodied AI and open‚Äësource models amid intense domestic competition. Source: CNBC, WebProNews.
Sprinkles Cupcakes shuts all stores: The 20‚Äëyear‚Äëold gourmet cupcake chain announced an ‚Äúorderly wind‚Äëdown,‚Äù closing U.S. shops and cupcake ATMs after a private‚Äëequity sale in 2012. Source: ABC7, New York Post.
Trump Media plans shareholder token: Trump Media & Technology Group (DJT, Financial) will distribute a new cryptocurrency to shareholders via Crypto.com, adding to its push into digital assets. Source: BBC, Al Jazeera.
IRS details car-loan interest deduction for U.S.-built vehicles: Taxpayers who bought new cars assembled in the U.S. in 2025‚Äì2028 may deduct loan interest, potentially benefiting makers such as Ford (F, Financial), GM (GM, Financial), Tesla (TSLA) and Toyota (TM, Financial). Source: The Detroit News.
DOE orders Colorado coal unit to keep running: The Energy Department directed Craig Station Unit 1‚Äîco‚Äëowned in part by Xcel Energy (XEL, Financial)‚Äîto remain online past its retirement date, drawing cost and reliability pushback. Source: AP, CNN.
Saving more tops 2026 personal‚Äëfinance content: Media launched ‚Äúlow‚Äëbuy‚Äù and 1% savings challenges with practical budgeting tips to rebuild cash buffers in a higher‚Äëcost environment. Source: CNN Business, Yahoo Life.
Mortgage rates hit 2025 low into year‚Äëend: Freddie Mac (FMCC, Financial) reported the average 30‚Äëyear fixed at 6.15%, aiding affordability and activity for lenders and originators such as Rocket Companies (RKT, Financial). Source: ABC News.
Holiday trading hours: retailers mostly open: New Year‚Äôs Day saw many chains operating with adjusted hours‚ÄîTarget (TGT, Financial), Walmart (W

News_Title: Is It Too Late To Consider BYD After Its Strong Multi Year Share Price Run?
News_Content:
Is It Too Late To Consider BYD After Its Strong Multi Year Share Price Run?
Simply Wall St
December 24, 2025 5 min read
In this article:
BYDDF
-2.94%
BYDDY
-3.32%
If you are wondering whether BYD is still a smart buy after its big multiyear run, or if the easy money has already been made, you are not alone. That is exactly what this article will unpack.
Despite some recent choppiness, with the stock down 1.5% over the last week and roughly flat over 30 days, BYD is still up 8.2% year to date and 3.1% over the past year, on top of a hefty 48.4% gain in three years and 49.9% in five.
These moves have come as BYD cements its position as a global EV and battery heavyweight, ramping exports and expanding its model lineup in key overseas markets. Investors have also been reacting to policy shifts in China and intensifying EV competition, which can quickly change how the market prices BYD's growth story.
In our framework, BYD scores just 1 out of 6 on undervaluation checks. That might sound underwhelming until you see how different valuation methods tell very different stories, and why the most useful way to think about fair value, which we will get to at the end, goes beyond a simple scorecard.
BYD scores just 1/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown.
Approach 1: BYD Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis
A Discounted Cash Flow model takes estimates of the cash a company can generate in the future and discounts those amounts back to what they are worth today, to arrive at an intrinsic value per share.
For BYD, the model uses a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity framework in CN¬•. The latest twelve months show negative free cash flow of about CN¬•29.1 billion, reflecting heavy investment and working capital swings. Analysts then expect free cash flow to turn positive and grow rapidly, with Simply Wall St extrapolating those forecasts so that by 2035 BYD could be generating around CN¬•101.3 billion in free cash flow.
After discounting this stream of cash flows back to today, the model arrives at an intrinsic value of roughly HK$111.24 per share. Compared with the current market price, this implies the stock is about 16.3% below this DCF-derived estimate of intrinsic value, indicating a potential valuation gap based on the model‚Äôs assumptions.
Result: UNDERVALUED
Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests BYD is undervalued by 16.3%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 909 more undervalued stocks based on cash flows.
1211 Discounted Cash Flow as at Dec 2025
Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for BYD.
Approach 2: BYD Price vs Earnings
For a profitable company like BYD, the price to earnings ratio is a straightforward way to gauge how much investors are willing to pay today for each dollar of current earnings. In general, stronger and more reliable earnings growth, and lower perceived risk, justify a higher PE multiple, while slower growth or higher uncertainty usually call for a lower, more conservative multiple.
Story Continues
